Exhibition Tour—Charles Marville: Photographer of Paris
Exhibition Tour—Now You See It: Photography and Concealment
The United States and Canada, 1800–1900 A.D.

credit line: The Elisha Whittelsey Collection, The Elisha Whittelsey Fund, 1986
description: This small, candid photograph—likely a half-stereo view—offers an illuminating “snapshot” of a typical late war meeting of Union generals, a “Council of War,” in a field near Massaponax, Virginia. The chaotic study is one of the most daring made by any Union photographer. To compose it, Timothy H. O’Sullivan transported his equipment to an upper window in the gallery of a Baptist church that offered a useful elevated perspective from which to view the scene. Ulysses S. Grant’s soldiers have removed the church pews and placed them under the trees; staff officers gather around to discuss the situation. Evidence suggests that it had been a disastrous day for the Union troops, as the losses were heavy and no strategic advantage had been gained. In the background are rows of horse-drawn baggage wagons and ambulances transporting supplies for the next day’s engagement and the wounded to field hospitals. In the foreground General Grant bends over a pew and looks over his shoulder at a large map held in the lap of General George Meade, head of the Army of the Potomac.
medium: Albumen silver print from glass negative
title: General Grant's Council of War, Massaponax Church, Virginia
